title: Question
text:
Question
What is the value of \(x\) in the following equation?
\[
x = \frac{3 + 1}{5}
\]
Round your answer to two decimal places.


Solution
After rounding, we get 0.80.


Meta-information
exname: Arithmetic extype: num exsolution: 0.80 extol: 0.01




 Back to top

text:

R Documentation

    method = c("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"))

    method = c("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"))

title: Code Blocks
text: This is the first topic file for Tutorial 1.

title: Code Blocks
text:
Code Blocks
Use knitr code blocks to include non-interactive R code.

## Add 2 and 2
2 + 2

[1] 4

## Divide 225 by 15 and print the result
(x <- 225 / 15)

[1] 15


Use quarto-webr code blocks for interactive R exercises.

Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.

Code Block Environments
A single execution environment is shared across code blocks of the same type.

All the knitr code blocks in a QMD file will share an evaluation environment.
Likewise for the quarto-webr code blocks


x^2

[1] 225



Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
knitr and quarto-webr code blocks to not share the same environment, though.

resid(fit)

Error: object 'fit' not found



Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.
If you want to share objects across code chunk types (e.g., to pose a practice problem using objects created in a knitr chunk), you can regenerate the required objects using a hidden code chunk of the appropriate type.

Don’t forget to set an appropriate seed, if you’re trying to regenerate a stochastic object.



Inline Code
Use knitr inline code chunks to embed R output in text blocks.

E.g., R says the squareroot of 2 is 1.4142136.

title: Images & Figures
text:
This is the third topic file for Tutorial 1.
arrange() orders the rows of a data frame by the values of selected columns.
Unlike other dplyr verbs, arrange() largely ignores grouping; you need to explicitly mention grouping
    variables (or use  .by_group = TRUE) in order to group by them, and functions of variables are
    evaluated once per data frame, not once per group.
Unlike base sorting with sort(), NA are:
An object of the same type as .data. The output has the following properties:
This function is a generic, which means that packages can provide implementations (methods) for
    other classes. See the documentation of individual methods for extra arguments and differences in behaviour.
The following methods are currently available in loaded packages: no methods found.
Other single table verbs: 
    filter(),
    mutate(),
    reframe(),
    rename(),
    select(),
    slice(),
    summarise()

title: Images & Figures
text:
Assets Directory
All pre-rendered assets (i.e., files that will not rendered/compiled into some other format) that you want to include in your website should live somewhere in the “/assets/” directory.

/assets/images/: Image files
/assets/figures/: Scientific figures (e.g., graphs, plots, diagrams)
/assets/docs/: Pre-rendered documents (e.g., HTML)

title: Images & Figures
text:
Images



A Nice Mountain View

title: Images & Figures
text:
Figures



Serial Multiple Mediation

title: Images & Figures
text:
Documents
Include a pre-rendered HTML files as part of this webpage.
R: Order rows using column values
  
  
  
  
  
  



  



arrange {dplyr}
R Documentation





  Order rows using column values

  Description

  
  

  Usage

  arrange(.data, ..., .by_group = FALSE)

## S3 method for class 'data.frame'
arrange(.data, ..., .by_group = FALSE, .locale = NULL)

  Arguments

  







.data
A data frame, data frame extension (e.g. a tibble), or a lazy data frame (e.g. from dbplyr or dtplyr). See Methods, below, for more details.


...
<data-masking> Variables, or functions of variables. Use desc() to sort a variable in descending order.


.by_group
If TRUE, will sort first by grouping variable. Applies togrouped data frames only.


.locale
The locale to sort character vectors in.

If NULL, the default, uses the "C" locale unless the dplyr.legacy_locale global option escape hatch is active. See the dplyr-locale help page for more details.
If a single string from stringi::stri_locale_list() is supplied, then this will be used as the locale to sort with. For example, "en" will sort with the American English locale. This requires the stringi package.
If "C" is supplied, then character vectors will always be sorted in the C locale. This does not require stringi and is often much faster than supplying a locale identifier.

The C locale is not the same as English locales, such as "en", particularly when it comes to data containing a mix of upper and lower case letters. This is explained in more detail on the locale help page under the ⁠Default locale⁠ section.





  Details

  Missing values

  

  
    
       always sorted to the end for local data, even when wrapped with desc().
    
    
       treated differently for remote data, depending on the backend.
    
  

  Value

  

  
    
       All rows appear in the output, but (usually) in a different place.
    
    
       Columns are not modified.
    
    
       Groups are not modified.
    
    
       Data frame attributes are preserved.
    
  

  Methods

  
  

  See Also

  

  Examples

  arrange(mtcars, cyl, disp)
arrange(mtcars, desc(disp))

# grouped arrange ignores groups
by_cyl <- mtcars %>% group_by(cyl)
by_cyl %>% arrange(desc(wt))
# Unless you specifically ask:
by_cyl %>% arrange(desc(wt), .by_group = TRUE)

# use embracing when wrapping in a function;
# see ?rlang::args_data_masking for more details
tidy_eval_arrange <- function(.data, var) {
  .data %>%
    arrange({{ var }})
}
tidy_eval_arrange(mtcars, mpg)

# Use `across()` or `pick()` to select columns with tidy-select
iris %>% arrange(pick(starts_with("Sepal")))
iris %>% arrange(across(starts_with("Sepal"), desc))

title: Module Template
text:
Welcome to our template module. Every module comprises a series of topical tutorials, such as the three linked below.
Each tutorial will comprise a series of interactive lessons with practice problems embedded throughout. Each tutorial section should be wrapped up with a knowledge quiz.

title: Module Template
text:
Learning Goals
After completing this module, you will be able to:

Another thing you should learn from Tutorial 2.

Click the button below to get started with the first tutorial.

text: Use this page to provide some kind of brief wrap-up.

title: Conclusion
text:
Next Steps
If your module feeds naturally into another, link that module through the button below as a suggestion for further study.

Here, we’re linking to the First Steps module.

title: Divs & Callouts
text: This is the second topic file for Tutorial 1.

title: Divs & Callouts
text:
Callout Blocks
Use callout blocks to highlight special information.






Note Title



Something noteworthy.








Tip Title



Here’s a tip for ya…








Important Title



This is very important!








Warning Title



You’ve been warned.








Caution Title



Proceed with caution.



Custom Callouts
This project uses the quarto-custom-callout extension to provide some bespoke callout blocks. This template already defines four such blocks.
A reading callout to highlight relevant, recommended literature.

I.e., These sources would be the required reading in a classroom context.







Reading



R4DS 2: Workflow Basics


A reading-advanced callout to highlight relevant, but technically challanging, literature.

I.e., These sources would be supplementary reference materials but not required reading in a classroom context.







Advanced Reading



Advanced R 2.2: Binding Basics


A resource callout to highlight related external resources.






External Resources



For a different take on these ideas, check out Andrew Heiss’ R Primers tutorial on the topic

R Primers: Programming Basics





Practice Callouts
The custom practice callout is reserved for inline practice problems.

The panel-tabset div nested within the practice div creates a set of tabs to organize the exercise components.
Each Level 2 heading inside the panel-tabset div defines a new tab.

In the examples below, the tab titles are specified through quarto shortcode variables.
These variables are defined in the _variables.yml metadata file.








Example Code Exercise




Regress Petal.Width onto Species using the iris dataset.
Create a normal Q-Q plot of the residuals.


 Interactive Editor Hint Solution



Please enable JavaScript to experience the dynamic code cell content on this page.


Remember what happens when you call the Base R plot() function on a fitted lm object.



First, we’ll use the lm() function to estimate the model.


fit1 <- lm(Petal.Width ~ Species, data = iris)


Then, we’ll use the default plotting method for lm objects to create the Q-Q plot.


plot(fit1, 2)



















Example Theory Question




 Question Solution


What is the answer to life, the universe, and everything?


42

title: Divs & Callouts
text:
Using the Website Margin
In the previous section, all callout blocks are placed in the website body. In most cases, however, callout blocks are better placed in the website margin.

Placing supporting elements like links, callouts, and references in the margin streamlines the main body content while keeping the supporting information near the relevant main body content.

To place content in the website margine, we use the column-margin div.

Example

title: Knowledge Quiz: Tutorial 1
text:
Note




Click the check-mark button to check your answer.
Click the question-mark button to see an explanation of the solution.






Which of the following expressions will return TRUE?

(8 - 1) == 7 & 7 >= (14 / 2)TRUE!TRUE!(6 > 7)(8 + 6) < (8 * 6)TRUE & FALSE




TRUE: 7 is equal to 7, and 7 is greater than or equal to 7
TRUE: Trivially
FALSE: Trivial negation
TRUE: 6 is not strictly greater than 7, and that result is negated
TRUE: 14 is strictly less than 48
FALSE: Trivially





What is the value of \(x\) in the following equation?
\[
x = \frac{3 + 2}{5}
\]
Round your answer to two decimal places.



After rounding, we get 1.00.




Use the following help file excerpt to answer the question below.








cor
R Documentation





Correlation, Variance and Covariance (Matrices)

Usage

var(x, y = NULL, na.rm = FALSE, use)

cov(x, y = NULL, use = "everything",
    method = c("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"))

cor(x, y = NULL, use = "everything",
    method = c("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"))

cov2cor(V)








What is the default value for the use argument of the cor() function?

The use argument does not have a defined default value."spearman""everything""Everythingmethod



The default value for the use argument is "everything".

Wrong: There is a default value defined for use.
Wrong: This is one of the possible methods
Correct
Wrong: The “E” should be lowercase
Wrong: This is an argument name







 Back to top

title: Question
text:
Which of the following expressions will return TRUE?



"foo" != "bar"
(8 + 6) < (8 * 6)
(8 - 1) == 7 & 7 >= (14 / 2)
"alice" == "bob" | "alice" == "alice"
!(6 > 7)
TRUE
FALSE
"foo" == "bar"
(8 - 1) == 7 & 7 > (14 / 2)
"alice" == "bob" | "alice" != "alice"
"alice" == "bob" & "alice" == "alice"
!TRUE
TRUE & FALSE

title: Question
text:
"foo" != "bar"
(8 + 6) < (8 * 6)
(8 - 1) == 7 & 7 >= (14 / 2)
"alice" == "bob" | "alice" == "alice"
!(6 > 7)
TRUE
FALSE
"foo" == "bar"
(8 - 1) == 7 & 7 > (14 / 2)
"alice" == "bob" | "alice" != "alice"
"alice" == "bob" & "alice" == "alice"
!TRUE
TRUE & FALSE

title: Question
text:
Answerlist

TRUE: “foo” is not equal to “bar”
TRUE: 14 is strictly less than 48
TRUE: 7 is equal to 7, and 7 is greater than or equal to 7
TRUE: “alice” is not equal to “bob”, but “alice is equal to”alice”
TRUE: 6 is not strictly greater than 7, and that result is negated
TRUE: Trivially
FALSE: Trivially
FALSE: “foo” is not equal to “bar”
FALSE: 7 is equal to 7, but 7 is not strictly greater than 7
FALSE: “alice” is not equal to “bob”, and “alice” is equal to “alice”
FALSE: “alice” is not equal to “bob”
FALSE: Trivial negation
FALSE: Trivially
